The next Oreva heard of his father was the sad news of his tragic end. His father had been killed in the war in Sierra Leone. The boy had been devastated. He just could not believe it. His shattered mother was inconsolable. 




For months, they went about stunned and shaken to their roots. They could barely accept the tragedy that had befallen them. Then, things became tough. His mother was struggling with the army authority to get her husband entitlement that did not seem to be coming. 




Then after eighteen months, they got paid the money. Two week later, they got notice from the office of the commandant of the barracks to vacate the quarters. His mother could not quickly get a new accommodation outside the barracks and the two weeks elapsed and they were still in the barracks.

His mother placed her hand on his head and told him he had to get set for school. That was the last time Oreva saw his father. He and his father were very close and he loves the man dearly. His father was always proud of him because he took his studies seriously.



"If I had been very serious in my school days, i would not be in army today. I'd probably be working in a bank or hospital. But I was too playful and that was why I ended up as an other ranked soldier and not even an officer," his father usually said. He had told his son that if he worked hard and wanted to be a soldier, he would be a commissioned officer. Oreva, even at such a young age, had never wanted to be a soldier.

For months, they went about stunned and shaken to their roots. They could barely accept the tragedy that had befallen them. Then, things became tough. His mother was struggling with the army authority to get her husband entitlement that did not seem to be coming. 




Then after eighteen months, they got paid the money. Two week later, they got notice from the office of the commandant of the barracks to vacate the quarters. His mother could not quickly get a new accommodation outside the barracks and the two weeks elapsed and they were still in the barracks.

His mother placed her hand on his head and told him he had to get set for school. That was the last time Oreva saw his father. He and his father were very close and he loves the man dearly. His father was always proud of him because he took his studies seriously.



"If I had been very serious in my school days, i would not be in army today. I'd probably be working in a bank or hospital. But I was too playful and that was why I ended up as an other ranked soldier and not even an officer," his father usually said.
